dt.t: {wi}suffice{/wi} it to say that they are dedicated, serious personalities

quotes.t: But what of the meteoroids that come from other large objects in the solar system? To escape from Venus or the Earth, matter must be ejected at a velocity of at least seven miles a second; on Mars, three miles a second will {qword}suffice{/qword}.

She's also decided that she can't countenance her mother, who gives Jane cash but demands that her daughter save every receipt or package to prove that she didn't spend the money on drugs. {qword}Suffice{/qword} it to say, their short-lived truce is over.

aq.source: {it}A Class Apart: Prodigies, Pressure, and Passion Inside One of America's Best High Schools{/it}

quotes.t: Thirteen years later, I still don't know exactly what to make of this letter. It goes without saying that a simple thank-you note, especially nearly a year late, would have {qword}sufficed{/qword}.

et: Middle English {it}suffisen, sufficen{/it} "to be adequate, be capable," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}suffis-,{/it} stem of {it}suffire{/it} "to be sufficient for, be adequate," Latinization of Old French {it}sofire, soufire,{/it} going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*suffīcere,{/it} alteration (with {it}ī{/it} from verbs such as {it}dīcere{/it} "to say") of Latin {it}sufficere{/it} "to provide, appoint, have enough strength or capacity, be adequate," from {it}suf-,{/it} assimilated form of {it}sub-{/it} {et_link|sub-|sub-} + {it}facere{/it} "to make, do" {ma}{mat|fact|}{/ma}
shortdef: to meet or satisfy a need : be sufficient —often used with an impersonal it
